description:
Generative AI, especially large language models (LLMs), has been advancing rapidly in recent years, offering unprecedented capabilities for natural language processing, computer vision, and other domains. However, these powerful technologies also pose significant challenges and risks for social justice and society, as they can be used to create and spread disinformation, manipulate public opinion, infringe on personal privacy, and undermine trust in institutions and information sources. A single additional like to a Facebook page that disseminates fake news leads, on average, to an electoral gain of 0.145 votes for populist parties. In this talk, we will explore some of these current and emerging threats of generative AI, as well as some of the possible solutions and countermeasures.
Maria will present the latest research and data on how LLMs are being used to generate and disseminate fake news, propaganda, and misinformation, and how this affects the political landscape and the democratic process. She will also examine how LLMs and AI are eroding our privacy at work, by analyzing how employers and security teams are using AI for surveillance, profiling of individuals, for the sake of corporate defense.

Dimitri will illustrate some of the practical examples of AI misuse and abuse, such as deep fakes, synthetic identities, phishing, and cyberattacks, and how they can harm individuals and organizations. He will also discuss how AI APIs are becoming the root of all evil, by enabling anyone with minimal technical skills and malicious intentions to access and exploit powerful generative AI models and services. He will discuss some of the ethical and legal frameworks and guidelines that are needed to regulate and monitor the use of generative AI, and to protect the rights and interests of the users and the society.


Large Language Models (LLMs) are significantly transforming the way we work. Within cybersecurity, professionals and researchers have identified an arms race: LLM-based tactics for both offense and defense trying to outpace each other. Companies mainly worry about their Intellectual Property being used to train these models. But,  
personal data is increasingly used to train data sets, and privacy authorities are starting - or should definitely start -  to worry about this. Yet how LLMs may harm impact individuals, social justice and society at large remains poorly understood. In this talk, Maria and Dimitri explore some of the current and emerging threats of generative AI to societies and social justice, as well as some of the possible solutions and countermeasures.
title: Exploring Generative AI’s Threat to Social Justice and Democracy

description:
The first team dedicated computer emergency response was founded in 1988 after one of the first worms had infected a major portion of the Internet of that time. Tiger teams testing systems to prevent incidents from occurring had already been at work for over a decade, though mostly for classified governmental systems.

Today, there are hundreds of incident response teams all over the world. They are all different in background, jurisdiction, and offered services. Many of them, often called cyber security centres, combine traditional incident response capabilities with preventive services such as product certification and systems auditing.

In this talk, I first set the scene for different variations of incident response teams: governmental, national, private, commercial, product-related, network, military, national and other flavors. I then detail the different kinds of services and functions these teams have, from first response and triage to incident analysis and further on to situational awareness and other proactive services. Then, I describe what the co-operation mechanisms are and how they operate. Along the way I'll focus on the different kinds of customers and how they benefit from the work of the teams.

I will often use the Finnish NCSC-FI as an example as that's where my personal experience comes from. I will use stories from handling actual incidents wherever possible to illustrate my points.


This talk is a crash course in the world of Computer Emergency Response Teams and National Cyber Security Centres. Hundreds of these teams strive to protect their respective corners of the internet from incidents and vulnerabilities. Unlike security operations centres, they usually don't have direct control of the protected systems. Instead, they rely on information exchange with their peers and co-operation networks to get timely advice on current threats to their customers.

Information exchange might not sound like much, but in practice it has saved us all from harm many times over. Come hear some of the stories.
title: CERT and NCSC 101

description:
This is a story about my journey to find logic bugs in macOS. During 2020 - 2023 I found a bunch of them and reported three major vulnerability chains from macOS. I will explain my methodology to find them and walk you through an exploit chain that compromises users' sensitive data with zero click.
Latest chain starts with a zero-click vulnerability in macOS Calendar, which allows an attacker to add or delete arbitrary files inside the Calendar sandbox environment.This will directly lead to arbitrary code execution. I will demonstrate how this can be combined with Gatekeeper evasion and TCC evasion with Photos to compromise user sensitive Photos iCloud data.

First part of the vulnerability chain was covered on my presentation at Disobey 2023.  Now with macOS Sonoma, all the vulnerabilities in chain are fixed and I can finally share all the details.


In this presentation I will tell my story how I found a zero-click vulnerability in macOS Calendar, which allows an attacker to add or delete arbitrary files inside the Calendar sandbox environment.This will directly lead to arbitrary code execution. First part of the vulnerability chain was covered on my presentation at Disobey 2023.  Now with macOS Sonoma, all the chained vulnerabilities are fixed and I can finally share all the details.

description:
Web crawling has been a thing ever since we've had content to crawl. It's been utilized for data retrieval, automation and in infosec: for recon.

By crawling our targets, we are able to extract crucial information about them. In today's web the frontend of your application provides a plethora of information about not just your frontend, but also your backend.

What has been lacking in the past however, is advanced tooling for detecting and enumerating API surfaces the application calls. While there are tools like FFUF that can enumerate these API's, they are doing it in a "spray and pray" mindset.

What if we could extract this information from our client given just the data the application itself uses? 

In this talk we'll be exploring a new Work-in-Progress project codenamed "Lurker", which aims to analyze the minified or unminified javascript of web applications, track calls to external API's, and enumerate the calls and their parameters for use in applications like FFUF and other API pentesting tools.


In this talk we'll be exploring a new Work-in-Progress project codenamed "Lurker", which aims to analyze the minified or unminified javascript of web applications, track calls to external API's, and enumerate the calls and their parameters for use in applications like FFUF and other API pentesting tools.

description:
I'll guide the audience through my journey of intercepting, analyzing, and ultimately disrupting a phishing campaign aimed at Finnish bank customers. From deobfuscating malicious code to tracing the breadcrumbs to a Telegram account, I'll unveil each layer of the operation. I'll also discuss responsible reporting of this information and how to take action. Finally, I'll demonstrate how to turn the tables on the criminals by feeding them convincing yet entirely random data with the hopes that it’ll throw a wrench in their operations.


Ever wondered what you could do with those pesky phishing emails besides hitting 'delete'? Have you ever wanted to fight back? In this talk, I'll walk you through how I did it, so that you can too—all from the comfort of your sofa. You'll learn how simple it can be to help protect the innocent by making life harder for criminals, all while having fun and learning new skills at the same time.
title: Muddying the Waters: Turning Clear Phishing Ponds into Murky Swamps

description:
The talk highlights different aspects of why I prefer a threat based approach in the current threat landscape, where it is important to shift actionable security improvements left, execute at great speed, and be a bit pragmatic when it comes to the approach, still keeping the security controls verifiable and having the right mind set when something needs to be done after that inevitable incident.


Risk based approach have for a long time been all the rave when it comes to cyber security. In this talk I talk why I prefer a cyber threat based approach over a cyber risk based one.
title: Why I prefer to focus on threats over risks

description:
While understanding and reversing malware is a highly skilled procedure, attacking the C2 itself rarely requires a lot of technical skills. Most of the C2 servers have the same typical HTTP problems that can be detected by off-the-shelf vulnerability scanners.

By exploiting low-hanging fruit vulnerabilities, an attacker can obtain unauthorized access to administrative functions, allowing them to command thousands of devices and further explore other attack vectors. This can give them access to administrator panels and malware source code, and result in the identity of threat actors being exposed.

Continuing the journey of how C2s evolved after my Defcon talk and how they fell for similar errors that lead into their pwning again.
This talk will also cover the ethical stance of security researchers and the communication with LEA on how those criminals can be taked down.


C2 servers of mobile and Windows malware are usually left to their own fate after they have been discovered and the malware is no longer effective. We are going to take a deep dive into the rabbit hole of attacking and owning C2 servers, exposing details about their infrastructure, code bases, and the identity of the companies and individuals that operate and profit from them.
title: A two-part Saga: Continuing the Journey of Hacking Malware C2s.

description:
An account in AWS acts as a security boundary, and resources in one account are by default isolated from those in other accounts. However, this boundary can be crossed by assuming IAM roles that are configured to trust IAM principals in other accounts. While such cross-account roles have many valid use cases, they sometimes enable attack paths that could be exploited by attackers to move laterally between accounts of an AWS organization.

Identifying such paths manually in large AWS environments by reviewing all the relevant configurations is practically impossible. AWS environment can have hundreds of accounts and thousands of IAM roles, all having multiple IAM policies affecting the effective access paths. 

In the presentation, I will describe typical ways attackers could exploit cross-account trust relationships in AWS environments. Moreover, I'll present how graph-theory can be applied to analyse large AWS organizations to identify potentially dangerous cross-account access paths.

The talk presents tooling that models IAM configurations of an AWS environment as a graph and performs automatic analysis of IAM policies to identify effective assume-role paths. The tooling presented in this talk will be open-sourced. 

The methodology and tooling presented in this talk are useful for security professionals for assessing the security of large AWS environments and removing unnecessary attack paths.


Cross-account IAM role trust relationships can enable complex and hard to detect attack paths in AWS environments. In large AWS organizations, analysing such paths manually is practically impossible due to many different configurations involved. But what if we could simplify such analysis a bit?

This talk will outline how attackers could exploit AWS IAM role trust relationships and demonstrate how to reveal the routes attackers could take inside your AWS environment.
title: Identifying Cross-Account Attack Paths in AWS Environments at Scale

description:
Wireless networks have become indispensable in today’s world, and Red Teams are increasingly using advanced Wi-Fi attacks to gain unauthorized access to these networks. This workshop will focus on advanced Wi-Fi attacks used by Red Teams to access corporate wireless networks (MGT). Participants will learn how to perform Wi-Fi reconnaissance, identify configuration errors in wireless networks, create fake access points for launching phishing attacks, evade WIDS, and more. The workshop is completely virtual, and participants will have access to a laboratory environment where they can experiment safely. Participants should have prior knowledge of Wi-Fi attacks on open networks, WEP, WPA2-PSK, and WPA2/MGT. The workshop covers advanced techniques for Wi-Fi reconnaissance, creating custom TLS certificates, fake access point attacks, MSCHAPv2 relay attacks, password spraying, ESSID stripping, and more in environments where setting up a RogueAP on corporate networks is not possible. The workshop also highlights the importance of wireless intrusion detection systems for security teams, with an example using Nzyme. Overall, this workshop is ideal for Red Team professionals looking to enhance their Wi-Fi attack skills as another vector for easily accessing corporate networks.


Learn advanced WiFi attacks used by red teams to gain unauthorized access to wireless networks in a 100% virtualized lab. Perform WiFi reconnaissance, advanced attacks against corporate networks evading security configurations and monitor alerts generated in a WIDS to understand defensive measures.
title: Advanced WiFi Attacks for Red Team Professionals

description:
"Don't believe the hype" is the theme for this years Disobey. In the spirit of the theme, I'm going to open up the so much hyped Zero Trust and what are the really good sides of the worst name in the history of security.


Zero Trust must be the worst name in the history of Security. But is it just a bad name? Does it really offer worthwhile goals or is it an overkill? I hear sales pitches for it, like for many other security solutions, that concentrate on "What we can't allow anymore because of changed security landscape" all the time. Why does security have to be so negative? A well done Zero Trust environment gives you "the ability to work as efficiently and securely, whether you are sitting in Starbucks or the corporate office" - Which I believe most of us want. Come and listen to this talk about rights and wrongs of how to achieve Zero Trust and how keep Security as what it's meant to be - a support function for a happy workforce.
title: Zero Trust - Dope or Nope?

description:
In this talk I will illustrate how the formation of cyber communities on local, regional and cross regional level is important in order to be able to withstand the cyber security challenges which our field of expertise comes across. 
The presentation will be focused on: what is the meaning of community?
How can it provide more purposeful connections as opposed to networking?
How can communities provide inspiration, motivation, sense of belonging and a place of purposeful sparring.
What has all of that to do with cyber?
How can our cyber security domain learn and improve by creating meaningful community based interactions?


Networking vs community. 
*Why is forming a sense of community in the cyber security scene important? 
*Have we managed to create meaningful connections within the cyber security domain that will help us as individuals or as entities (public or private) improve our cyber security posture?
*Why is it important to create a cyber resilient individual or entity?
The formation of cyber communities can help solve a lot of the pain points in the field of cyber, such as attracting and retaining talent, dealing more effectively with coordinated and targeted attacks, building a more accurate threat intelligence picture.
Case studies presented to strengthen the argument: 
*A.	Nordic Financial CERT 
*B.	Women4Cyber Denmark
title: The rising flame of community engagement

description:
This talk is a mashup of 7+ peer-reviewed papers from JYU.fi (yeah, cool top-level research "Made in Finland!") spanning work over 3+ years:
- Cybersecurity of COSPAS-SARSAT and EPIRB: threat and attacker models, exploits, future research (SpaceSec23 NDSS)
- Towards a Unified Cybersecurity Testing Lab for Satellite, Aerospace, Avionics, Maritime, Drone (SAAMD) technologies and communications (SpaceSec23 NDSS)
- On the (In)Security of 1090ES and UAT978 Mobile Cockpit Information Systems – An Attacker Perspective on the Availability of ADS-B Safety- and Mission-Critical Systems (IEEE Access)
- Cybersecurity attacks on software logic and error handling within ADS-B implementations: Systematic testing of resilience and countermeasures (IEEE TAES)
- Cybersecurity Attacks on Software Logic and Error Handling Within AIS Implementations: A Systematic Testing of Resilience (IEEE Access)
- GDL90fuzz: Fuzzing 'GDL-90 Data Interface Specification' Within Aviation Software and Avionics Devices - A Cybersecurity Pentesting Perspective (IEEE Access)
- On Apache Log4j2 exploitation in aeronautical, maritime, and aerospace communication (IEEE Access)
- dump1030: open-source plug-and-play demodulator/decoder for 1030MHz uplink (IEEE AESM)

Video demos of cool and funny crashes of satellite, avionics, aerospace, maritime software will be demonstrated.


Hacking around with Satellite, Aerospace, Avionics, Maritime, Drones: Crashing/Exploiting at the speed of SDR.

This talk is a mashup of 7+ peer-reviewed papers from JYU.fi (yeah, cool top-level research "Made in Finland!") spanning work over 3+ years, where we overview application security in critical domains such as Satellite, Aerospace, Avionics, Maritime, Drones (SAAMD), and how they can be attacked via unprotected interfaces of ADS-B, AIS, ACARS, GDL90, EPIRB and similar protocols.
title: Hacking around with Satellite, Aerospace, Avionics, Maritime, Drones: Crashing/Exploiting at the speed of SDR.

description:
“Cybersecurity is a critical concern in the gaming industry due to the significant financial investments, personal data, and intellectual property at stake.  Game developers, publishers, and players all have a vested interest in maintaining a secure gaming environment.
Cybersecurity in the gaming industry is essential to protect player data, maintain a secure gaming environment, and safeguard intellectual property. Both players and game developers need to remain vigilant, educate themselves about potential threats, and employ best practices to ensure a safe and enjoyable gaming.” experience.

Game developers, publishers, and players all have a vested interest in maintaining a secure gaming environment. Cybersecurity in the gaming industry is essential to protect player data, maintain a secure gaming environment, and safeguard intellectual property. Both players and game developers need to remain vigilant, educate themselves about potential threats, and employ best practices to ensure a safe and enjoyable gaming experience.

Major key aspects of cybersecurity in the Gaming Industry include: Data Protection, Securing Game Code, Securing Player Accounts, Anti-Cheating Measures, Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) Attacks defense, Phishing Scams, Network Security, Securing Game Code, Patching and Updates, Third-Party Security, Incident Response, Regulatory Compliance, Secure Development Lifecycle


Cybersecurity is a critical concern in the gaming industry due to the significant financial investments, personal data, and intellectual property at stake.

description:
The idea is that we have a "web shop" where people who have the authorization to spend money can order a deployment with given "products" (in 1.0 release only TAK server and the always shared user/device enrolment system/IdP). Then a fully automated and headless deployment system (Pulumi & Terraform) starts to bring everything up. When systems are up the enrolment can start, with a PoC version we have had someone who never used this system to enrol 100 "average joes" in 45min into using ATAK/iTAK with just the built-in online instructions.

Talk will start with some more info on what we do, how and why.  Will continue with a bunch of "war stories" (pun intended) about things that went well (or not) and how we ended up with the various approaches we did end up with.

As much as possible is open source at https://github.com/pvarki and we try to provide streamlined deployments on other platforms to people who want to deploy SA-system for their volunteer fire department for example.

The speakers are volunteers in this project and do not represent the FDF in any way or form.


A volunteer group has been developing a system for very quickly making available situational awareness tools like TAK (https://tak.gov/) to ad-hoc groups with BYOD. Due to the context this is developed for security of enrolment, device revocation etc are extremely important.

description:
This workshop is about hacking the AI.

We will first go through the fundamentals of responsible AI practices, including security testing basics & principles. We are going to take the hacker's approach to AI use cases and see if we can make them do something they aren't supposed to.

Participants will have the opportunity to test out a few models from beginner to advanced level.

description:
In this deeply technical talk, I'll chronicle my bug bounty hacking journey that started with the discovery of a peculiar domain and spiraled into callbacks, tokens and successful exploitation of the target in most interesting way.

The journey began with the stumble upon an anomalous domain and the pivot to an expired one via its IP address, subsequently purchased and set up with wildcard DNS, revealing incoming Rancher fleet agent requests with tokens. After reporting this anomaly to the bug bounty program a proof of the impact of the finding was requested.

With every twist, the expedition took unexpected turns; setting up servers, spoofing responses, and achieving Remote Code Execution from wrong parts of the software, continually oscillating between breakthroughs and dead ends. This thorough exploration uncovered vulnerabilities in Kubernetes/Rancher, leading to a new strategies and methodologies, each step illuminating new facets of the intricate security labyrinth that this CTF like quest offered!

Venturing further into the unknown, modifications in URI and bearer tokens connected the target clients to a hacker controlled Rancher server and allowed to control the target nodes. With each step forward, new doors opened and the mounting of the host root disk inside the container allowed for a comprehensive breach of the target server!

This presentation will not just be a recount of the intricate process leading to a $10,001 bounty but a profound insight into the fragile essence of forgotten domains, a testament to the relentless pursuit of knowledge in the ever-evolving world of hacking. Audience members will leave with enriched understandings of the vulnerabilities lurking within domains and an enlightened perspective on the benefits of the bug bounty programs.


A thrilling journey into the intricate exploitation of web of domain intricacies and exploits. This presentation will unravel an intriguing narrative where a seemingly innocuous delve into an unusual domain metamorphoses into a meticulous bug bounty exploration, ultimately unveiling profound vulnerabilities and leading to a full compromise of company infrastructure. In a span of 2.5 weeks, a seemingly inconsequential expired domain metamorphoses into a treacherous trap, illuminating weaknesses in Rancher, Kubernetes, and varied client endpoints. This journey, punctuated by failed attempts and discarded research, is a testament to the relentless pursuit of cybersecurity knowledge and the potential rewards of diligent, innovative exploration.
title: Breaking Badly: Domains, Callbacks, Tokens and Exploits

description:
The cat and mouse game played by attackers and defenders has always served a singular purpose: to improve defenses against modern threats. In recent years however, it seems that breach notifications are higher than ever, so what's going on?

In this talk, we will dig into the technical details of how these attacks continue to be pulled off. Tactics and tradecraft tips will be shared, along with practical recommendations for both offensive and defensive teams. Of course, it wouldn't be a red team talk without some good stories now would it?


Red teamers and pentesters are paid to simulate real threat actors, but who is really mimicking who? This talk will analyze technical details from recent breaches and provide a red teamer's perspective on attacks that are working against modern defenses, useful tradecraft tips, and how defenses can be improved. Stories will be shared, and hype debunked. xD
title: KEYNOTE : Circling Dragons: Red Team Lessons From Modern Breaches

description:
Microsoft Azure and Entra ID form core components of many organisations' infrastructure. One of the key elements of the platform is the integration of services with Azure Monitor which enables telemetry collection and analysis.  Our research into the platform discovered a technique which could be used by external users to hide malicious activity by modifying the username surfaced in generated logs. This could be used by an attacker with sufficient access in the tenant to hide their activities and make attribution difficult. As part of the talk we will provide a brief background on the Azure Monitor service and how it interacts with the other core services within the platform and explain the differences between standard tenant users, external accounts and guest accounts. We will then explore some of the example scenarios we have reviewed and present a demo of the issue within an Entra ID tenant. The talk will finish with approaches on how to discover and mitigate against the issue with the tenant.


As organisations develop their cloud usage, and mature their cloud security operations; attackers have had to identify and develop methods to avoid detection. Our talk will explore techniques that would allow attackers to evade Graph Activity logs, along with methods to enable malicious actions to blend in with legitimate activity.
title: Smoke and Mirrors: How to hide in Microsoft Azure

description:
This presentation is about the application of Ken Wilber’s Integral Theory in the field of cybersecurity. The conference theme “Don’t believe the hype” raises attention, among other things, on the human factor – the multitude of ways human agents can be tricked into compromising confidentiality, authenticity and in turn a plethora of valuable assets.
 
We also acknowledge the age of AI as a new situation for security professionals. It provides more powerful tools for threat actors and defenders alike. What does this mean for the security and hacking community?

There is no one-size-fits-all solution. We come from different backgrounds, have different motivations, provide security for different sectors and have various combinations of experience and responsibility. Hacking as a technical craft implies breaking boundaries and being able to create something previously unknown, but these skills on their own do not warrant socially responsible behavior. Politics, culture, the historical situation and need for recognition among peers can all play a part. Even morality itself ultimately proves to be a vague phenomenon.

How can Ken Wilber’s Integral Theory be of use here? Sometimes called A Theory of Everything, this framework integrates the key findings of dozens of developmental psychology theories in a systematic way. First, it deals with the Four Quadrants: 1) our inner experience, 2) our intersubjectivity, 3) our physical or perceived personality and 4) our place in social systems.

Second, it presents levels of development, equally resonating with human psychological growth, historical change and socio-political systems. This is the core of his theory, and it sheds clear light to our current age: how geopolitical tensions escalate between democratic and autocratic systems, how we deal with the post-truth era and the ecological crisis, and how we need to rethink agency with the rise of more capable AI systems.

In the suggested presentation, I will first present the main tenets of Wilber’s theory and then provide a set of feasible applications for the Disobey community, ie. a toolbox for security professionals. The second part will build on current and most relevant cybersecurity topics near the conference date. Although not deeply technical as such, the talk will do its best to appreciate hands-on themes that most attendees can relate to.

I believe Wilber’s theory can enhance critical thinking and clarity of vision. Further, I hope it can bring a fresh perspective on how we understand motivation and community in the context of security, as well as how the global situation might unfold.


With the rise of AI we look for tools to deal with security risks caused by deception, gullibility and the human factor. Ken Wilber’s Integral Theory is a holistic framework on human, societal and cultural development that provides one of the most comprehensive toolkits for understanding motivation and change. I will present the main tenets of the theory and suggest ways how security professionals and the hacker community can benefit from these insights.

description:
What happens when a malware infects a machine? How good does a malware developer need to be in order to by pass an antivirus? How well can an EDR spot new malware threats?  How can I get started  experimenting with self-developed (safe?) malware? If you have ever asked any of these questions, I have answers for you.


What happens when a malware infects a machine? How good does a malware developer need to be in order to bypass an antivirus? How well can an EDR spot new malware threats?  How can I get started  experimenting with self-developed (safe?) malware? If you have ever asked any of these questions, I have answers for you.

This presentation walks you through the process of script kiddie malware development, DLL sideloading malware technique and explains how the malware could be used against a victim. After the theory part I will share the results I have gotten from my testing with different AV and EDR systems. There is no one system that can save you, no matter the hype.
title: I'm a script kiddie, bypassing your antivirus and EDR systems

description:
In this workshop, we’ll alternate between theory, examples, discussions, and practical exercises around the following themes: 
* Your experiences: what makes training good or bad?
* Scoping the training and selecting the topic
* Target audience
* Learning goals 
* Types of learning and the benefits of each: classroom, lectures, hands-on workshops, webinars, etc.
* Using stories
* Interactivity
* Gamification 
* Low-budget sources for visualization
* Checking learning outcomes

During the workshop, you can draft content for your next infosec training or security awareness info sessions and also get ideas and feedback from others. Bringing your laptop is recommended.


Are you looking to create a DIY security awareness training for your entire staff? Or perhaps you’d like your team to learn your company processes, such as incident response?

If you want to go beyond bullet points and avoid putting your training participants in a coma, this workshop is for you. We’ll go through the elements of engaging and interactive training that makes learning fun and effective. Using the exercises in this workshop, you can draft your next awesome information security training. 

No more boring slide shows with a useless multiple-choice exam at the end! Let’s create fun training content with stories and interactivity instead.
title: Beyond Bullet Points: Creating An Engaging & Effective Security Training

description:
Creating offensive tools is a wild ride. Opensourcing them even more so. 
What happens when a tool gets mass adoption?

There's a lot of moral and ethical considerations to tackle while going through release cycles.

In this talk we take a peek in to a short history of a tool called Fuzz Faster U Fool, how and why it was created, observing its mass adoption and challenges throughout the years. 
What should you consider when releasing and maybe open sourcing a tool? All are contributions and feature requests good and valid? What's hard in open source maintenance and how to deal with haters.


Open source maintenance comes with a burden of a ton of hard decisions related to design, technical aspects, user interface, even coding styles. 
When software gains mass adoptation and gets its spot in workflows of the large audience additional considerations should be taken into account. 
Things like backwards compatibility and intuitive UX for new features are now on table.

By sharing experiences of rapid adoptation and hurdles through the lifespan of ffuf, this talk is aiming to shed some light on these issues, as well as answering questions like: 

Feature requests and even some large contributions where the contributor might have worked for weeks for a feature might not be compatible with the software philosophy or roadmap, how to deal with those?

How much hand holding is necessary and should it be implemented if the cost is flexibility?

How far the responsibility of the software maintainer reaches when the tools are used in a harmul way and what they can do to mitigate it?

description:
Kubernetes, which at its core is not a container orchestrator, [but an engine for keeping any kind of infrastructure in control](https://thenewstack.io/k8s-is-not-the-platform-or-is-it-and-we-all-misunderstood/), serves as a case example for an uniform API server. Its API server has a formalized uniform “[flow control](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/debug-cluster/flow-control/) -> [authentication](authentication) -> [authorization](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/validating-admission-policy/) -> [validation of request body](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/validating-admission-policy/)” request chain before any “business level” logic is applied, and at the end [audit logs](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug/debug-cluster/audit/) are generated as configured.

In recent years, Relation-based access control (ReBAC) has increasingly been studied and applied industry. The [ANSI/INCITS Next Generation Access Control (NGAC) standard](https://standards.incits.org/apps/group_public/project/details.php?project_id=2328) was released in 2016, and Google wrote about their global and consistent [ReBAC system in 2019](https://research.google/pubs/pub48190/). In recent years, there are good reference implementations of ReBAC data models available, such as [PM-Master](https://pm-master.github.io/pm-master/) (NGAC), [SpiceDB](https://github.com/authzed/spicedb) and [OpenFGA](https://github.com/openfga/openfga) (Zanzibar). ReBAC declaratively models the authorization state as a graph with nodes and directed edges, and is able to support both RBAC and ABAC flows within its data model, as well as naturally graph-based authorization types (user X can have recursive access to folder Y’s children documents).

Lucas has implemented a [PoC for this in a Kubernetes context](https://github.com/luxas/kube-rebac-authorizer), re-implementing the [RBAC](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/rbac/) and [Node](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/node/) authorizers using Google Zanzibar-inspired data model; however in the talk we’ll not focus on Kubernetes-specific details but cover more generic key take-aways that developers can apply in their API servers and control planes.


The top 1 security risk in OWASP’s latest API Security Risks lists is [“Broken Object Level Authorization”](https://owasp.org/API-Security/editions/2023/en/0xa1-broken-object-level-authorization/), and the third one [“Broken Object Property Level Authorization”](https://owasp.org/API-Security/editions/2023/en/0xa3-broken-object-property-level-authorization/). Thus, helping developers mitigate these risks through best-practices and frameworks can be highly beneficial for our community.

This talk will discuss some means that could be applied to build API servers (or more generally, control plane) in a way they are less susceptible to these attacks: through 



* uniformity of API server structure (this is probably quite known to most security professionals, but good to cover), and
* relation-based access control (ReBAC), a superset of both RBAC and ABAC, which allows for finer-grained and declarative access control.

This gives us, a way to avoid “oops, I forgot to implement the authorization if check for this API resource (or field)” and escape the inevitability of an unmaintainable amount of imperative if checks in the API servers such as “if the authenticated user belongs to a group with magic string ‘employees’, it should have access to all documents with prefix /company_public”.

A declarative model of the authorization model, and a graph based structure of the authorization state can be audited, visualized and pentested more easily than custom code for each resource in the API.

In the end, Lucas will do a demo of this paradigm working in action. All code is open source and fully reproducible for anyone. The audience will after this talk have practical knowledge about how they can formalize their access control in an extensible, uniform and auditable way for their projects.
title: Beyond RBAC: Avoid broken ACLs in control planes with declarative Relation-based Access Control

In recent years, Relation-based access control (ReBAC) has increasingly been studied and applied industry. The [ANSI/INCITS Next Generation Access Control (NGAC) standard](https://standards.incits.org/apps/group_public/project/details.php?project_id=2328) was released in 2016, and Google wrote about their global and consistent [ReBAC system in 2019](https://research.google/pubs/pub48190/). In recent years, there are good reference implementations of ReBAC data models available, such as [PM-Master](https://pm-master.github.io/pm-master/) (NGAC), [SpiceDB](https://github.com/authzed/spicedb) and [OpenFGA](https://github.com/openfga/openfga) (Zanzibar). ReBAC declaratively models the authorization state as a graph with nodes and directed edges, and is able to support both RBAC and ABAC flows within its data model, as well as naturally graph-based authorization types (user X can have recursive access to folder Y’s children documents).

Lucas has implemented a [PoC for this in a Kubernetes context](https://github.com/luxas/kube-rebac-authorizer), re-implementing the [RBAC](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/rbac/) and [Node](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/node/) authorizers using Google Zanzibar-inspired data model; however in the talk we’ll not focus on Kubernetes-specific details but cover more generic key take-aways that developers can apply in their API servers and control planes.


The top 1 security risk in OWASP’s latest API Security Risks lists is [“Broken Object Level Authorization”](https://owasp.org/API-Security/editions/2023/en/0xa1-broken-object-level-authorization/), and the third one [“Broken Object Property Level Authorization”](https://owasp.org/API-Security/editions/2023/en/0xa3-broken-object-property-level-authorization/). Thus, helping developers mitigate these risks through best-practices and frameworks can be highly beneficial for our community.

This talk will discuss some means that could be applied to build API servers (or more generally, control plane) in a way they are less susceptible to these attacks: through 



* uniformity of API server structure (this is probably quite known to most security professionals, but good to cover), and
* relation-based access control (ReBAC), a superset of both RBAC and ABAC, which allows for finer-grained and declarative access control.

This gives us, a way to avoid “oops, I forgot to implement the authorization if check for this API resource (or field)” and escape the inevitability of an unmaintainable amount of imperative if checks in the API servers such as “if the authenticated user belongs to a group with magic string ‘employees’, it should have access to all documents with prefix /company_public”.

A declarative model of the authorization model, and a graph based structure of the authorization state can be audited, visualized and pentested more easily than custom code for each resource in the API.

In the end, Lucas will do a demo of this paradigm working in action. All code is open source and fully reproducible for anyone. The audience will after this talk have practical knowledge about how they can formalize their access control in an extensible, uniform and auditable way for their projects.

description:
Logs are a vital component for maintaining application reliability, performance, and security. They serve as a source of information for developers, security teams, and other stakeholders to understand what has happened or gone wrong within an application. However, logs can also be used to compromise the security of an application by injecting malicious content.

In this presentation, we will explore how ANSI escape sequences can be used to inject, vandalize, and even weaponize plaintext logfiles of modern applications. We will revisit a vulnerability class thats been dormant for over two decades, dig into old terminal injection research and log tampering techniques from the 80-90s, and combine them with new features. With the pure intention to create chaos and mischief in the modern cloud cli’s, mobile, and feature-rich DevOps terminal emulators of today. Shine some light on the consequences, and learn how and why we should avoid passing on malicious escape sequences into our logfiles. To ensure that users actually can trust the data inside their logs.

Join us on this “not so black and white,” but rather quite colorful ANSI adventure and learn how to prevent a forensic nightmare.


Ever interacted with a logfile from a external facing system using cli tools like, cat, grep or awk using a terminal? Well then this presentation is for you! We will explore how ANSI escape sequences can be used to inject, vandalize, and even weaponize plaintext logfiles of modern applications.
title: Weaponizing Plain Text: ANSI Escape Sequences as a Forensic Nightmare

description:
Detailed Outline:

1. Introduction: The Hype Surrounding Purple Teaming 
- Origins and Why It's Trending 
- Distilling Fact from Fiction: What Purple Teaming is NOT 

2. Case Studies: Beyond the Hype 
- Case Study 1: Bypassing and Evading EDR Tools 
-- Real-world implications of EDR evasion 
-- Collaborative Purple Team response and results 

- Case Study 2: Operating Within an On-Prem Domain Environment 
-- Practical challenges faced within on-prem domains 
-- How unified teamwork can outpace individual efforts 

3. Strategies Beyond Buzzwords 
- Actionable methods that have proven effective, time and again 
- Avoiding pitfalls: Steering clear of strategies that are more hype than help 

4. Conclusion: The Practical Future of Purple Teaming 
- Steering the narrative: How to keep the conversation factual and grounded 
- Embracing continual evolution in the face of an ever-changing threat landscape


While buzzwords like "Purple Teaming" frequently circulate in the cybersecurity realm, not all discussions about it are rooted in practical, real-world application. Delving beyond the buzz, this talk seeks to demystify Purple Teaming by providing tangible examples of its efficacy. Through real-world cases, we'll dissect how the combined might of Red and Blue Teams can offer unparalleled security outcomes. 

Talk objectives
- Debunking Myths: Address common misconceptions and overhyped beliefs about Purple Teaming. 
- Real-World Validation: Offer case studies showcasing Purple Teaming's genuine value in addressing diverse security challenges. 
- Strategies Beyond the Buzzwords: Illuminate proven strategies that have consistently yielded success in Purple Teaming exercises. 
- Looking Forward: Contemplating the future of Purple Teaming in the evolving threat landscape.
title: "Purple Teaming in Action: Beyond the Hype"

description:
With technology available that enables us to control every aspect of our home in a quick and convenient way, more and more parts of our lives require us to hand over our data to companies and third parties they work with. 

In this talk, we'll look at a couple of examples (a robot hoover, and a smart washing machine). The talk will be broken down into the following sections:

1. Collection up front: what exactly does the privacy policy for each say? How transparent is each company about what they collect? What data do they keep vs share/sell? Who exactly are the "third parties and other partners" that get the data collected?

2. What can be inferred from this data collection? Why is it even valuable in the first place? 

3. Exploring each app using tools like Burpsuite and Wireshark to analyse how often over a set period data gets collected, how much gets collected in reality (compared to what is stated in the privacy policy), and identifying the third parties more concretely via some OSINT if it isn't immediately obvious.

4. Can we do anything about it? Are there any methods available to us that allow us to reduce/cut out this data collection?


Smart home technology allows us to turn on our heating so it's nice and warm before we get through the door, or control all the lights, TVs, and speakers in the house. It can even tell us when the fridge is running low on something, or when the laundry cycle has finished. But, by embracing these conveniences, how much are we giving up in the process via the apps they need to function?

We're going to take a look at a couple of apps that accompany these smart devices throughout this talk. We'll start with diving into the privacy policies of each to see just how up-front they are about the data they're collecting and who it gets shared with/sold to. After that, we'll move onto where the data is going, how often it gets collected, and ultimately which third parties also get to know you.
title: How Much Dirty Laundry Are Your Smart Home Devices Airing About You?

description:
Generative AI has caught the imagination of the world and the hype about what can be done with it is going on strong. However, underneath the hype, it has some serious issues with f.ex. data and model poisoning, hallucinations, and prompt injections. This talk cuts through the hype on what generative AI, and especially large language models, are good for. And more importantly the talk focuses on how we keep the solutions using it safe and secure with examples of where failures to do so have ended up in the press. While the concepts of MLSecOps and LLMOps are on their own hype cycles and rising in importance, the necessary skillset can be hard to find and replacing it can be difficult as there is more terminology than clarity.

As anyone with the skills to utilize API calls can implement the capabilities of generative AI in their applications, it becomes vital to up-skill developers, ML experts and cyber security experts to ask the right questions, implement the necessary processes, and utilize required tools to keep these applications safe. DevOps and especially DevSecOps is proposed as a good mindset to begin with, but alone it will not suffice with the silent ways in which machine learning fails. This presentation focuses on the blurry lines between DevSecOps, MLOps and MLSecOps and identifies one possibility of the skillset, tooling, and processes necessary for keeping applications safe as well as identifying the terminology these skills fall under, to enable cutting through the hype, up-skilling the necessary people, and building something we can safely use that won’t land the company using it in the press.


This talk looks at the core of Generative AI and proposes securing it from DevSecOps best practices appended with MLSecOps.
title: Securing GenAI? How far will DevSecOps take you and how to go further?

description:
Many teenagers have exceptional technical ability, lots of free time, and unlimited curiosity. This is a recipe for either

1. A highly successful career in cyber security or
2. A highly successful career in cybercrime.

Unfortunately, many youngsters pick the latter choice, starting off as innocent script kiddies and progressing bit by bit, each time getting a little more risky. In the end, some become full-blown cyber criminals. The steps along the way can seem small and insignificant, but picking up on them, stopping the person in time, and redirecting them more towards option 1 is critical.

This presentation is done in collaboration with Testausserveri Ry, an organisation dedicated to helping young people in Finland develop as ethical hackers and programmers, as well as KRP, the Finnish National Bureau of Investigation. Both are very aware of the problem and have worked together to figure out how to motivate kids away from going into cybercrime at a young age. I will present some of our facts and findings from this discussion, as well as pointers on how you, as an individual or as a company, can help with the situation.


I managed to avoid this fate, but I was almost on the wrong path. Find out what I, you, and the National Bureau of Investigation (KRP) can do to tackle cybercrime.
title: I was almost a cybercriminal

description:
Most techies try to hone and perfect their technical skills but don't really focus on social skills improvement at all and through mentoring, I have noticed that a lot of people need their eyes opened to the wonderful world of social skills. So, I want to highlight and hopefully inspire people to seek information about these skills and improve them and even give you some tips and tricks along the way.


My personal journey into social skills, how I acquired them, what I did along the way and some advice and tips to different topics within the social skills spectrum and how that can help you to get security on the top of the agenda via influencing and other fun social skills. I try to inspire especially technical people to start learning more about social skills, because they will help you in your career and help you have a bigger impact.
title: Hacking hearts and minds

description:
The workshop gives basic understanding of why and how to do mobile forensics. All techniques covered utilise open source or free tools available to anyone.

The workshop will cover the following topics:
+ Mobile forensics general process
+ Data collection on iOS and Android devices
+ User activity from native OS data
+ Third party application analysis

The workshop includes a CTF to test the newly achieved forensics skills. Don't forget to bring your own laptop.


This workshop will give an introduction to data collection and analysis methods to conduct mobile device forensics on iOS and Android devices as well as an opportunity to test your new skills in a CTF. Don't forget to bring your own laptop!

If you want to participate the CTF, you can already download the evidence and supporting materials from: https://bit.ly/3HYdtDR (Google Drive).

description:
In this talk, we will review findings of cases where the cl0p ransomware group stole data from several organisations using vulnerabilities in Managed File Transfer (MFT) services. The presentation will focus on the MOVEit MFT related SQLi vulnerability, which was disclosed in May 2023. Before public disclosure, cl0p was already actively exploiting the vulnerability. By exploiting the vulnerability, cl0p gained access to the MFT application and exfiltrated all data stored in the application. This presentation presents the activities of the ransomware group, a timeline from reconnaissance to exfiltration, and an analysis of the backdoor used by the attacker. The presentation is built on investigation notes from real incident response investigations and make recommendations for organisations using MFT applications to minimize the risk in the future.


Cl0p grop has been targeting MOVEit servers for data exfiltration and extortion. This is a story who are cl0p, who were their targets, and how they managed to steal your data.
title: I like to MOVEit MOVEit

description:
Project Lead Viivi Lehtinen and inspector Aki Somerkallio from Cybercrime Centre at the
National Bureau of Investigation run an early intervention project called Cybercrime Exit
which is part of the special preventive operations of the Police. The project seeks to tackle cyber-dependent crime committed by young people against information networks and information systems. Cyber Offender Prevention operations aim to ensure that offenders, from potential to prolific, have made informed choices and are fully aware of the legal and life implications of online crime alongside legitimate opportunities for their digital interests and skills. The aim of preventive work is
also to free up investigators’ time and attention by ensuring that Instead of focusing on preventable crime, detectives might also be able to focus on tracking professional criminals, meaning those who
choose the path of cybercrime. Find out how the National Bureau of investigation is
collaborating and adding their own experience in implementing a national operating model
for young people who have committed or are at risk of committing serious cybercrime.


Modern societies face problems that cannot be solved with the traditional way of policing.
The numbers of cyber offenders are rising, the damage they cause is alarming and the
average age of offenders is declining. The police simply cannot arrest themselves out of
cybercrime. The relationship between hackers and law enforcement is often perceived as somewhat adversarial. There may be historical reasons for this, which are perhaps amplified by how each side is portrayed by the media and popular fiction. But just as law enforcement has
recognized the value of public-private partnerships in their fight against crime, it has become
apparent that the hacker community has a lot to offer to the prevention of juvenile
cybercrime. In this talk Project Lead and Inspector of the National Bureau of Investigation
share their thoughts and experience on how to increase and cultivate the dialogue and trust
between young enthusiasts, the infosec community and the police for the prevention of cybercrime.
title: Everybody relax, it's the Police

description:
Themes:
1.	Interconnectedness: Uncover the hidden threads weaving EU regulations into the cybersecurity fabric, shaping our interconnected digital world.
2.	Use cases: Immerse yourself in real-world examples showcasing how EU regulations are applied in cybersecurity scenarios, offering actionable insights for businesses.
3.	Anticipate the future Get a glimpse into the crystal ball of cybersecurity. What EU regulations lie ahead? Prepare yourself for the dynamic landscape of tomorrow.

Takeaways

This talk will take your curiosity to the next level as you

•	Attain a nuanced understanding of EU regulations in crucial cyber areas such as Directive on the Resilience of Critical entities/”CER”, (Regulation on measures for high common level of cybersecurity in the EU institutions, bodies and agencies), Cyber resiliency act “CRA” and  Cyber solidarity act
•	Acquire strategies to not just comply but thrive within the framework of EU regulations.
•	Understand how it works, how it breaks and what is the key element for EU ecosystem

•	Feel the spark to actively engage in European initiatives and join the ranks of influential working groups.


Unlock the secrets behind the EU hype! As regulations on AI, cybersecurity, social media, data, and resilience take center stage, curiosity builds. But do we grasp the true impact ? Embark on a 45-minute journey with us, delving deep into deciphering the EU's influence on the cyber ecosystem.
Objective: Demystify EU regulations and kindle the flame of curiosity in our cybersecurity community. From ENISA working groups to standard mirror committees, we unveil insights on navigating this complex regulatory landscape. It's more than compliance—it's about seizing opportunities, exploring use cases, and preparing for what's on the horizon.
title: EU hype decoded: CISO Mindx2 crystal ball insights and call for action!

description:
In my talk I will describe our experiences in incorporating cloud security posture management into our DevOps workflow and how that has helped us work with configuration issues in a collaborative fashion. 

Some of the topics I will cover are:

- Our approach to triaging findings
- How we embed cloud configuration management into our CI/CD pipelines
- Examples of how CSPM rules can be used to align to organizational policies
- Examples of where configuration management helped us avoid disaster
- Tips on where to get started with CSPM

I'll also share my personal experiences as the Product Security Lead for SAS Customer Intelligence solutions and how a generalist non-developer like me can use tools such as CSPM to bridge the gap between controls in a compliance framework to actual code & configuration and how CSPM helps discussion between compliance & development.


**What if I told you that your code security is not enough?** You need to ensure your deployment is secure as well! Developing Software-as-a-Service applications requires security both from a development perspective as well as from a deployment perspective. Facts: 
- The Verizon 2023 Data Breach Investigations Report shows that misconfigurations are a persistent cause for data breaches over the years and account for a fair chunk of confirmed breaches [(verizon.com/dbir)](https://verizon.com/dbir).
- According to [OWASP Top 10:2021](https://owasp.org/Top10), in 90% of the applications they examined, they found some form of misconfiguration.

This is where Cloud Security Posture Management (CSPM) solutions come into play. They work as a bridge between security, operations and development to ensure the code is deployed in a secure fashion and helps organizations avoid breaches due to configuration errors.

It doesn't matter if your code has zero vulnerabilities based on your sophisticated SAST/DAST/IAST scans and if you've ensured your third-party libraries are all patched using your state-of-the-art SCA scans if your cloud configuration allows unauthorized access to your object storage. In addition, underlying configuration mistakes can lead to disaster when an attacker chains their attacks and is able to escalate their privileges, move laterally or establish persistence.
title: Beyond Code Security: How CSPM Can Help to Secure Your Cloud and Avoid Configuration Disasters

Some of the topics I will cover are:

- Our approach to triaging findings
- How we embed cloud configuration management into our CI/CD pipelines
- Examples of how CSPM rules can be used to align to organizational policies
- Examples of where configuration management helped us avoid disaster
- Tips on where to get started with CSPM

I'll also share my personal experiences as the Product Security Lead for SAS Customer Intelligence solutions and how a generalist non-developer like me can use tools such as CSPM to bridge the gap between controls in a compliance framework to actual code & configuration and how CSPM helps discussion between compliance & development.


**What if I told you that your code security is not enough?** You need to ensure your deployment is secure as well! Developing Software-as-a-Service applications requires security both from a development perspective as well as from a deployment perspective. Facts: 
- The Verizon 2023 Data Breach Investigations Report shows that misconfigurations are a persistent cause for data breaches over the years and account for a fair chunk of confirmed breaches [(verizon.com/dbir)](https://verizon.com/dbir).
- According to [OWASP Top 10:2021](https://owasp.org/Top10), in 90% of the applications they examined, they found some form of misconfiguration.

This is where Cloud Security Posture Management (CSPM) solutions come into play. They work as a bridge between security, operations and development to ensure the code is deployed in a secure fashion and helps organizations avoid breaches due to configuration errors.

It doesn't matter if your code has zero vulnerabilities based on your sophisticated SAST/DAST/IAST scans and if you've ensured your third-party libraries are all patched using your state-of-the-art SCA scans if your cloud configuration allows unauthorized access to your object storage. In addition, underlying configuration mistakes can lead to disaster when an attacker chains their attacks and is able to escalate their privileges, move laterally or establish persistence.

# Attention
If you don't come prepared, as stated in the requirements below, we are not gonna wait for you setting up your system, as we don't have time for that.

## What is this workshop about?

An unrecorded workshop session in which we solve an interactive TryHackMe (THM) box hacking challenge together.  
Learn and apply tools, tactics and procedures for analyzing a vulnerable box.

The goal is to have a joint hacking session in which you will learn something as well as be able to put what you have learned into practice. You should actively participate in the workshop.

## Requirements
* Own laptop
* TryHackMe Free Account
* Solid basic knowledge about Linux and the command line interface (CLI) (navigating through the filesystem, executing programs, man pages, basic cli tools (cd, mkdir, ls etc.)
* Search engine of your choice
* Kali Linux via:
  * as virtual machine (recommendation) OR
  * Kali Linux Live System via Flash drive OR
  * Installed directly on your laptop

### Linklist
* [TryHackMe Registration](https://tryhackme.com/signup)
* [Kali Linux Virtual Machine Images](https://www.kali.org/get-kali/#kali-virtual-machines)
* [Kali Linux Live Boot Images](https://www.kali.org/get-kali/#kali-live)

## How will the session work

I will choose an unnamed challenge box in advance from THM. This challenge is suitable for beginners and includes a web and Linux part. Except for the challenge box pre-selection and the setup of the virtual machine (VM) based on Kali Linux, there are no preparations from my side.
During the workshop we will try to find and exploit the vulnerabilities together. The idea would be that the workshop participants provide ideas how we can attack the box. I would then demonstrate suitable as well as unsuitable ideas live. In doing so, I will show you common tools and methods I use to approach such problems.

Maybe we'll manage to successfully pwn the box together!  
Check out the [Hacking Cheatsheet](https://github.com/Hetti/Hacking-Cheatsheet)


A supervised hacking session. Get familiar to tools, tactics and methodologies for analysing vulnerable online services.

description:
Presentation tries to elaborate how electronic thinggies are being produced, how to recon, approach and perhaps even attack or defend IoT (or any electronics) equipment out there. Presenter has tried several different approaches, some has failed, some succeeded and wants to share his own best-practises with the wider community. After this presentation hopefully there will be some folks who will continue the HW-journey on their own with some new approaches and ideas. We'll be talking about non-soldering/soldering approaches, nrf5340DK boards, lifting firmwares, debugging on hardware itself and which methods has been found useful and which definetly not. Presentation also includes a real-life example of taking back control of your very own home router!


HW-hacking all the things, tips and tricks with a budget! The presentation aims to raise awareness of HW-hacking among hackers and common people. Share some backgrounds from electronics manufacturing, testing phases, development and other included processes . Also, the idea is to show how to possibly lift firmware from range of devices and offer an easy'ish solution to build your boot camp for HW-hacking. No soldering or super wonky equipment required to start hacking, easy entry-level!
title: Hardware Hacking all the things, on a budget - You can do it too!

description:
# Wi-Fi Roaming Security and Privacy

## Quick basics of Enterprise Wi-Fi (EAP) authentication and roaming

 * What is EAP and how it works?
 * How RADIUS based Wi-Fi roaming hierarchy (e.g. eduroam) works?
 * How peer-to-peer roaming federation (e.g. OpenRoaming) works?

## Improved evil twin attack

 * In roaming federations not only the known SSIDs, but also Roaming Consortium Organisation Ids (RCOI) can be used to trick the user device trying to connect to a network is looks secure to the user
 * The user device can be tricked to reveal more information about the device and user, which then can be used to track user or badly configured profiles can be used to make man-in-the-middle attacks possible
* how to defend / mitigate?

## Remote brute-force / denial-of-service attack

 * When roaming networks are considered, the AAA server (usually RADIUS, may be HLR/HSS as well) can be targeted via any network belonging to the same roaming federation for remote brute-force / denial-of-service / injection attacks
 * how to defend / mitigate?

## Injection attack via roaming hierarchy

 * RADIUS/EAP authentication requests has fields that are processed and logged by all servers on the roaming authentication path -- this means that it is possible to deliver some information to be processed by all those servers even without successful authentication
 * log4j, SQL, JavaScript, XSS, HTML ... payload could be inserted in the authentication requests
 * how to defend / mitigate?

## Hidden channel communication via roaming hierarchy

 * Roaming EAP authentications may require multiple rounds of messages for successful authentication -- failing authentications may send even more
 * For an organisation, which is part of the roaming federation it is possible to setup a modified AAA server and a 802.1X supplicant in user device, which can transfer information between the AAA server and user device without the device even authenticating to the roaming network
 * This can be used for communications or even VPN functionality if really needed
 * how to defend / mitigate?

## VLAN hopping / discovery attack

 * Enterprise Wi-Fi devices often support and utilise a functionality called dynamic VLAN assignment
 * In dynamic VLAN assignment  the AAA server describes via standard and/or vendor specific RADIUS attributes to which VLAN the device should be connected based on the authentication
 * Some Wi-Fi equipment also reveal the VLAN in the RADIUS access request they send
 * In VLAN hopping / discovery attack, the adversary with an access to a AAA server belonging to the federation can return adversary chosen VLAN attributes to try to drop the attacker's device into VLANs meant for attacked organisations employee/company devices connections thus gaining an access to the VLANs not otherwise accessible to roaming users
 * how to defend / mitigate?

##  MAC address randomisation, does it really work?

 * how does it work?
 * does MAC address randomisation provide privacy in roaming networks?

## What else can be used for tracking?

 * username i.e. outer EAP identity in username-password and client certificate authentication
 * IMSI in SIM authentication
 * combined these to improved evil twin AP attack makes it possible to collect statistics and calculate (potential) users
 * RADIUS accounting, sent often in clear text, protected only sometimes by TLS (RadSec)
 * how to defend/mitigate?

## Ongoing IETF work to improve RADIUS and Wi-Fi roaming security

 * Summary of the ongoing work in IETF's radext working group


Wi-Fi network security presentations are often about breaking the link level (radio) encryption or deploying evil twin Wi-Fi access points to perform man-in-the-middle attacks. This presentation focuses instead to the security and privacy in Wi-Fi roaming, offloading and federated networks, where there are different issues and vectors to utilise or defend against.

description:
Nina Nissilä works as a Deputy Director General in Kela, the Social Insurance Institution of Finland. She is in charge of IT and Shared Services. Customer centric digitalization, cyber security, innovation, and business development are close to Nissilä’s heart. Between 2020 and 2023, Nissilä has been a member of the Finnish Government’s high level Technology Advisory Board. Starting from summer 2023, she has been a member of European Social Insurance Platform’s Board of Governors. In her previous job positions, she has established a service design oriented digital team D9 for the Finnish Government and worked as a business lead in CGI and Tieto among others. Nissilä is CIO and Digital Leader of the year 2023 by Tivi IT Magazine.

In her keynote, Nina Nissilä opens up Kela’s critical role in Finnish society and what cyber and data security means in business where there is a high need to secure the most sensitive data for people living in Finland.

Some: www.linkedin.com/in/ninanissila


In her speech Nina Nissilä opens up Kela’s critical role in Finnish society and what the cyber and data security means for a business where there is a high need to secure the most sensitive data of the people living in Finland.

Social media www.linkedin.com/in/ninanissila
title: KEYNOTE : Securing Social Security - Kela's View on Information Security
